The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. The most promising approach is to use the language of category theory, which has been successfully applied to a variety of mathematical subjects. However, the category of Hilbert spaces and operators on it is not a category of mathematical objects, but rather a category of mathematical constructions. This paper provides a set of axioms for a category of mathematical objects that is equivalent to the category of Hilbert spaces and operators on it. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of hosts. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian parasite, and we show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to P. hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Read more)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused a global health crisis and has led to a high mortality rate. The SARS-CoV-2 virus is able to evade the host immune response by blocking IFN-mediated antiviral signaling. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s food production will have to increase by 70% by 2050 to meet the demand of a projected 9 billion people. This increase will be challenging, especially in the tropics, where the optimum growing temperature is exceeded in many places. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially in the major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that the extent of grass consumption varied widely among species, from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, but dietary composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the need for more comprehensive and accurate diet information to understand the role of large mammals in ecosystems. (Less)

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses expect the crisis to last for many months. These findings have implications for policy, as well as for our understanding of the economic consequences of the pandemic.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris larger than 1 mm by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory to study the formation of the solar system and the early solar system. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This indicates that the solar system formed in a relatively pristine environment.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most fundamental traits in nature. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output and the mechanisms by which external energy sources increase reproductive output. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output and the factors that limit it. This framework can be applied to other organisms and traits. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in the striatum of a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and its oligomeric forms. VX-765 also preserved tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of the mouse model. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would have important implications for the treatment of MSA. Further studies are needed to confirm these results in a larger animal model of MSA and to assess the potential of VX-765 in clinical trials.

It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). A state-dependent crystallographic study of KcsA-T75A proves that, on activation, the selectivity filter transitions from a nonconductive and deep C-type inactivated conformation to a conductive one. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is being investigated in a variety of animal models, including humans. The gut microbiome is also important for the health of herbivores, and the role of the gut microbiome in the health of herbivores is being investigated in a variety of animal models, including humans. The results presented here support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi are important contributors to the health of herbivores.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism

The ability to design and fabricate mechanical devices with desired behaviors is essential for the development of smart and intelligent systems. However, the design of mechanical devices is often limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of the structures. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design and fabricate mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme responses. The strategy is based on the optimal synthesis of multimaterial structures that seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The structures are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach, which is based on the principle of maximum information entropy. The structures are then manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, which is based on the principle of minimum energy. The structures are finally assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and fabricate mechanical devices with specific behaviors for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of humans and other mammals. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of evolution. The hemoglobin system is a complex of four globin proteins, two alpha and two beta, which are encoded by two distinct genes. The alpha-globin gene is expressed in the fetus and the beta-globin gene is expressed in the adult. The alpha-globin gene is expressed in the adult, but the beta-globin gene is expressed in the fetus. The alpha-globin gene is expressed in the fetus, but the beta-globin gene is expressed in the adult. The hemoglobin system is a major target of evolution. Here we show that the hemoglobin system is regulated by a developmental switch in the expression of the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1).

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite the tremendous advances in cancer treatment, the survival rate of patients is still low. One of the main reasons is the resistance of cancer cells to the treatment. In this study, we found that the mutation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers cancer cells resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids. We also found that the mutation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway induces lipogenesis, which is a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis. Thus, we developed a combination of mTORC1 inhibition and ferroptosis induction, which resulted in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. This study provides a new strategy for cancer treatment. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension in young patients.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that transformed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but not early-seral–associated species. Our findings highlight the importance of maintaining older forests and the need to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is a major challenge for the pharmaceutical industry. In this work, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. We used a computational approach to predict the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics toward the ribosome. We then synthesized the compounds predicted to be the most active and tested them in vitro and in vivo. The best compound is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is more accessible and soluble than the latter. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work demonstrates the potential of computational approaches to accelerate the discovery of new antibiotics. (Less)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish fauna is one of the most diverse and best-known freshwater fish communities in the world. The lake is a unique system, with a large, shallow lake occupying a deep basin. The lake has been studied for over a century, and the lake level has been monitored continuously since 1960. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability in the tropics, which shows that the lake level has been highly variable over the last 1.3 My. The record reveals a dramatic shift in hydroclimate at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, which is consistent with far-field climate forcing. The lake level was lower before 800,000 years ago, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT highstands dominated the record, but these were interrupted by prolonged intervals of extreme drought. The hydroclimate variability exerted a profound influence on the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock; the geographically extensive habitat reconfiguration provided novel ecological opportunities, enabling new populations to differentiate rapidly to distinct species.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is thought to be triggered by one or more bolide impacts. The impact hypothesis is supported by varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules at the YDB. However, the origin of the magnetic grains and microspherules is unclear. We show that the magnetic grains and microspherules are terrestrial in origin. The magnetic grains and microspherules are from a single impact event in northeastern North America, and the impact is the source of the magnetic grains and microspherules in the YDB sites.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. CTLA-4 deficiency in adult mice results in lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. However, this is not fatal. CTLA-4 deficiency induces preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells, but this is not sufficient to prevent the development of autoimmunity.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and traced the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to efficiently enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We manipulated population size such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Our results indicate that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and cognition.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that the amount of C1q protein accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration, is highly dependent on APOE alleles. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth, and its formation is still a mystery. The nucleation mechanism of the inner core is one of the most important issues in understanding its formation. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. We found that the nucleation rate of the bcc phase is much higher than that of the hcp phase under the inner core conditions. This result suggests that the bcc phase is the first phase to nucleate, and the hcp phase is nucleated later. This two-step nucleation scenario solves the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are reduced in marijuana abusers. These reduced responses are associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the reduced brain DA responses to methylphenidate may contribute to the addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is the defining feature of modern humans, and the brain’s processing of language is the most studied cognitive process. Despite decades of research, the brain’s mechanisms for language comprehension remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also outperform all other models on a key dataset of neural responses to sentences in humans. We find that these networks’ neural fits generalize across datasets and imaging modalities, and that model architecture appears to substantially contribute to neural fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the language comprehension mechanisms in artificial neural networks and humans are more similar than has previously been appreciated. Together, they highlight the potential for artificial neural networks to advance our understanding of the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, the stability of DL methods is still an open problem. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a fundamental paradox, which we address by establishing a classification theory of stability. We also introduce a fast iterative restarted network (FIRENET) that we prove is stable and numerically verify is fast and stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major global crisis. It is also a major opportunity to learn about the human condition. This article discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago, which is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. The experiment’s critical design flaws were overlooked at the time, and the study is now widely cited as proof of the inability to understand exponential growth. This article discusses the flaws of the experiment and the implications for the scientific community and the public.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for millennia. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are responsible for the two major forms of the disease, namely, lepromatous and lepromatous-like leprosy. The genomes of these two species have been sequenced, and here we present the near-complete genome sequence of M. lepromatosis. We also compare the two genomes and discuss the implications of the findings for our understanding of the evolution of the leprosy pathogens.

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources for quantum information processing. They are also the two main ingredients of thermodynamics, the latter being the foundation of statistical mechanics. Therefore, the study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy is of fundamental importance for the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated systems. We show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the most challenging part of the problem. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement. This result is a major step forward in the understanding of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a rapid and effective solution. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. This vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture, has a large-scale production capacity, and is highly protective in animal models. This vaccine candidate is a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with rodent and human ectoparasite vectors being proposed. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of using a Bayesian approach to model outbreaks, as it allows for the inclusion of many data points and the consideration of multiple hypotheses. This approach is particularly useful when the data are sparse and/or the number of outbreaks is limited. Finally, we show that the Bayesian approach is also useful to assess the relative importance of different hypotheses.

The evolution of brain size is a key topic in comparative neurobiology. However, it is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of an animal. In this study, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of an animal. We also show that the evolution of the brain is not a linear process but rather a series of discrete shifts in the number of neurons. These shifts are associated with the evolution of new brain functions.

The HSP90 chaperone family is implicated in a wide range of cellular processes, including cell growth and death. The TRAP1 member of this family is found predominantly in mitochondria, where it is thought to regulate the activity of the Bcl-2 family of proapoptotic and antiapoptotic proteins. We have found that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament dynamics. It is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell migration, cytokinesis, and vesicle trafficking. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF action is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF binds to actin filaments and that this binding is enhanced by a mechanical torque. We propose that this torque is generated by the filaments’ connection to other filaments, and that it enhances ADF severing activity. We demonstrate that this mechanism is critical for ADF to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of ADF in cell migration and cytokinesis. They also suggest that ADF’s activity can be modulated by the mechanical properties of the filament network. This may be important for understanding the role of ADF in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes greater hunger and desire for food and a willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose and may promote feeding behavior. The results also suggest that fructose may be a more effective ingredient in food and beverage products than glucose. These findings have implications for our understanding of the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on health and for the development of strategies to reduce consumption of these products. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, as we found that the settlement happened in a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous way. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a step forward to understand the history of the Indian Ocean region. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. The results suggest that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms and for our understanding of the role of social networks in our lives.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis in cells. The presence of chemical modifications in the mRNA sequence can have profound effects on the translation of the mRNA. In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can significantly alter the rate of translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNA can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNA can have a significant impact on the translation of the mRNA. Our work provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on the translation of mRNAs. (Read more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and use of time. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and the feeling of being able to say that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities predicts positive changes in these outcomes over time. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results suggest that the evolution of aquatic lifestyles is a major driver of the evolution of body size in mammals.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication is a major factor in the pathogenesis of the common cold. Here, we show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at the cool temperature found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. We also show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the MAVS protein, which is a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs). We further show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype is rescued by genetic deficiency of MAVS or the type I IFN receptor. These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent rhinovirus replication and may lead to the development of therapeutic strategies to reduce the severity of the common cold. Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect surfaces. This mechanism is important for the pathogen to attach to surfaces and to promote the production of virulence factors and biofilm formation. Our results demonstrate that type IV pili are a mechanochemical sensor that measures the mechanical activity of the pili and regulate the activity of the pili, thereby promoting long-term surface attachment. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing is a unique feature of P. aeruginosa and may be important for the pathogen to adapt to its environment.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide contamination of surface water and its effects on aquatic biodiversity. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the persistence of the virus in wildlife. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human infections are rare. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern. This paper examines the reasons for the proliferation of large dams in the developing world and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of intense research. However, the immune response in AD is still poorly understood. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type affected in AD, are the source of a variety of potent inflammatory factors. These factors are released in the absence of extracellular Aβ plaques and cell death, suggesting that they are a consequence of the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and thus may be a key component in the AD pathogenesis.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method to study folding at high resolution and have applied it to the maltose binding protein. The method is based on the observation that the folding of a protein is accompanied by a change in the chemical environment of the protein. We used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein and found that the folding process is composed of two steps. The first step is a fast compaction of the protein into a polyglobular state. The second step is a slow formation of a native-like folding intermediate.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on small RNAs. However, the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the differential impact of Np4-capped 5′ termini on the rates at which they are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the immune dysfunction during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine deprivation is involved in the immune dysfunction observed in sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a potential therapeutic strategy to restore immune function in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. Our results also suggest that arginine deprivation may be a common mechanism involved in the immune dysfunction observed in sepsis and other diseases. This hypothesis could be tested in future studies. (Read more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time such that the rate of change of all relevant length and time scales is equal. The SOC state is characterized by a power-law distribution of event rates, which is a signature of SOC. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we study the sandpile model in the thermodynamic limit and show that it exhibits SOC behavior. We also show that the sandpile model is a continuous version of a certain scaling limit of a cellular automaton, which is a tropical toy model for the sandpile model.

Diamond is a promising material for quantum applications, but its electronic properties are difficult to control. We show that diamond can be metallized reversibly via strain engineering, which opens up opportunities to control its electronic properties. This work provides a general framework for strain engineering of diamond, which can be extended to other materials.

The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of plants is well established. The role of plant-associated microorganisms in the evolution of animals is less well understood. Here, we show that the evolution of the immune system in animals is linked to the evolution of plant-associated microorganisms. We also show that the evolution of the immune system in animals is linked to the evolution of plant-associated microorganisms.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of intersexual continuity. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We combined proteomics and isotopic labeling to study the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that seminal fluid proteins are rapidly incorporated into sperm, and that female-derived proteins become the dominant component of the sperm proteome after mating. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Our research provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of intersexual continuity. (Read more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large, multidomain plasma protein that binds to the platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) receptor, triggering platelet aggregation. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD), and the A1 domain in VWF is a major target for therapeutic intervention. We show that force application switches the A1 domain of VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD and for the design of therapeutic strategies. The results also suggest that the A1 domain of VWF is in a conformational state that is poised for activation. This state is likely to be important for other functions of VWF. The results are relevant to other proteins that bind to receptors on cells.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has been the target of only a few large-scale studies. This study is a comprehensive analysis of the human virome, and provides a resource for future studies of the impact of viruses on human health. The study also provides a resource for the study of the human microbiome, which is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the target of decades of study.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models due to the complexity of the process. Observations of ACI are challenging because of the lack of high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosol and cloud properties. We introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to overcome this conundrum. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL by conducting observations over Beijing, China, and analyzing the aerosol–cloud interaction. The observations provide substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. We expect that this instrument will make a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of intense interest for many years. The temperature of the surface is important because it is the temperature at which life on Earth exists. The temperature of the surface is also important because it is the temperature at which the chemical reactions that drive the evolution of the planet occur. In this paper, we use the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes to infer the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the nervous system and heart. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are controlled by two gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability.

Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a complex process that is poorly understood. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses the binding of its erythrocyte-binding antigen, EBA175, to glycophorin A on the RBC surface to alter the biophysical properties of the cell. We show that this leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension and a reduction in the bending modulus of the RBC membrane. We also show that this change in the membrane properties is directly correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. These findings suggest that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This is a major advance in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion. (Less)

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection in low humidity environments and may lead to the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus in such settings. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree of nested phrases. However, whether and how the brain builds such structures is unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate the brain’s processing of linguistic structure. We found that high-gamma power increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity was consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Formal model comparison indicated that the model of multiword phrase construction provided a better fit than probability-based models at most sites in superior temporal and inferior frontal cortices. Activity in those regions was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that is involved in development and homeostasis. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH GABA neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH GABA neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the hypothalamus. This circuit is important for the development of overeating and may contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth and productivity, and the most important limiting factor for crop yields in many regions of the world. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and nitrogen-fixing bacteria would therefore be a major breakthrough in agriculture. Here, we report the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a major step toward the development of a synthetic nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis. This article is protected by copyright. We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. Our results also suggest that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Our results have implications for the design of forest monitoring and governance systems in the Amazon and elsewhere.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize sound sources in their environment. The auditory organs of animals are all part of the body of the animal, and the size of the auditory organs is constrained by the size of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear by outsourcing its hearing to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave. The spider can also supersize its web to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study also provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of sensory function in animals.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We estimate that a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 (2.96–4.21) million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 (4.52–6.52) million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with no approved vaccine available for low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing and elicits high-affinity antibodies. These antibodies are able to neutralize two variants of concern, and presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD can be used in a variety of vaccine platforms, and we anticipate that it will be useful in the global fight against COVID-19.

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is implicated in the development of a variety of human cancers. In the zebrafish Danio rerio, the RTK DrLtk is involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the neural crest. Here, we show that zebrafish DrAlkals are able to activate DrLtk and human ALK in vitro. We further show that loss-of-function alleles of zebrafish DrAlkals cause ectopic iridophore development, whereas gain-of-function alleles lead to a complete loss of iridophores in zebrafish larvae and adults. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of the ALK family of RTKs in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This is the first report of a ligand–receptor interaction in the ALK family. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of human cancers.

The emergence of plague from its Yersinia pseudotuberculosis progenitor is a key event in the history of the genus Yersinia. The study of ancient plague genomes has revealed the emergence of the plague pathogen, but the diversity of the progenitor and the timing of its divergence from the pseudotuberculosis lineage are still debated. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical time for the spread of plague across Eurasia. Our results show that the progenitor of plague was not adapted to fleas, and that the emergence of plague occurred in Eurasia, rather than in Africa, as previously thought. This study provides a more complete picture of the history of plague during its formative years. (Less)

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a key question in climate science. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has released massive amounts of SOC to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in sequestering SOC on grassland-derived Mollisols remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that incorporate perennial pastures and livestock can sequester SOC and increase microbial biomass and C-use efficiency. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to mitigate climate change and support food production. This study also highlights the importance of long-term field experiments in understanding the efficacy of soil health management practices. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize viruses that pose the greatest risk of spillover and spread in humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify host, viral, and environmental risk factors contributing to zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This resource will be of interest to policy makers and health scientists.

Nectar is the reward that flowering plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms underlying this trait are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red nectar trait is widespread in vertebrate-pollinated plants and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of floral rewards and the mechanisms underlying the attraction of pollinators to plants. (Less)

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions, but the population-level processes occurring during the period of cultural change are poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a panel of functional loci in a sample of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. We show that the genetic ancestry of men closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The ability to rapidly identify the pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used a global cloud-based platform to sequence pathogen RNA from 464 febrile patients and 23 afebrile persons in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. We found that chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce settings is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied to other resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate epidemics. (Less)

The human genome is replicated in a complex process involving the replication of DNA strands in the 5′ to 3′ direction. This process is carried out by DNA polymerases that synthesize new DNA strands in the 3′ to 5′ direction. The lagging strand synthesis is catalyzed by the pol δ enzyme, which requires the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) to maintain its activity. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for the replication of the lagging strand, but the mechanism by which it maintains its activity is unknown. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and found that it maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. This behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most fundamental questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be evolved to have catalytic activity, but the evolution of catalytic RNA that can replicate RNA has not been achieved. Here, we report the evolution of a catalytic RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA. This polymerase ribozyme can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Furthermore, the polymerase can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules, including aptamers and ribozymes. Thus, the polymerase ribozyme is able to replicate and convert RNA into functional molecules, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life. This work provides a step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability to regulate intracellular copper content is therefore an important aspect of fungal physiology. The xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper. This study demonstrates that copper homeostasis is a function of the xan BGC, and that secreted xanthocillin-derived isocyanides have antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings have implications for our understanding of fungal physiology and the role of copper in fungal–fungal and fungal–bacterial interactions. (Read more)

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) SiO2 polymorph that is a product of high-temperature, low-pressure (high-temperature) silica magma petrogenesis. The tridymitic mudstone has ∼40 wt.% crystalline and ∼60 wt.% X-ray amorphous material and a bulk composition with ∼74 wt.% SiO2.
