Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity and a major cause of economic losses in agriculture and forestry. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that this change is driven by the increasing frequency of late-spring frosts. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees to frost damage are region-specific, and that these strategies are changing in response to climate change. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this subset is not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains an IL-17A+ phenotype and is required for the development of colitis, whereas the other, which is deficient in IFN-γ, is dispensable for colitis development. These results suggest that Th17 cells can have two distinct functions in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in several genes, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. We now report a method to rapidly and easily produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for therapeutics. This will enable us to accelerate ALS research and development of therapeutics. This method will also be useful for other neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in pathogen virulence and transmission. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that is expressed by the tick Ixodes scapularis and is known to alter the composition of the tick microbiota. We show that iafgp alters the integrity of the gut barrier and the peritrophic matrix, which are critical for the survival of the pathogen in the gut lumen. We also show that iafgp alters the composition of the gut microbiota, which is important for the survival of the pathogen in the gut lumen. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen can use an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This knowledge will be useful for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Read more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in avian evolution, as it is the last common ancestor of the tail and the modern avian tail morphology is derived from the tail of basal nonavian dinosaurs. The study of the evolution of the avian tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin and diversification of birds. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, that adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are green. The reason for this phenomenon is poorly understood, but it is thought to be related to the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin, a compound that is normally found in the blood. In this study, we show that the presence of high concentrations of biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and that this phenomenon is related to the presence of a group of serpins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. This study also provides a better understanding of the evolution of color in vertebrates. (Less)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The ability of breast cancer cells to form tumorigenic cells, which are termed cancer stem cells (CSCs), is a major obstacle to successful treatment. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, a demethylase that demethylates NANOG mRNA, which encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG mRNA levels are increased, and the breast cancer stem cell phenotype is induced, in an HIF- and ALKBH5-dependent manner. ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of breast cancer cells that are tumorigenic, and knockdown of ALKBH5 expression in breast cancer cells reduces their capacity for tumorigenicity. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. This study also provides a mechanism for the role of ALKBH5 in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. (Read more)

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was a major innovation, and the source of this parchment has been a long-standing controversy. We report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment used to make books, and may be particularly useful for the study of medieval manuscripts. (Less)

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, and the extinction interval is 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization precedes the extinction and is punctuated by a sharp negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. The precise age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, and will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Abridged)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the orphan nuclear receptor superfamily and plays important roles in various biological processes, such as metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is still unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We further demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides insights into the function of RORα in the intestine. (Read more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.0-Å resolution. The structure of the spike in complex with ACE2 reveals a number of residues that are mutated in the G614 mutant virus, which is more infectious. We show that the G614 mutant spike adopts a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. These results provide insights into the differences between the two mutants and may help to inform vaccine design. (Read more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of an atom are determined by the energy required to remove an electron from it. This energy is called the chemical potential. The chemical potential of an atom is the sum of the chemical potentials of the electrons in the atom and the vacuum. We show that the chemical potential of an atom is a function of the electron density of the atom. We show that the chemical potential of an atom is a function of the electron density of the atom. We show that the chemical potential of an atom is a function of the electron density of the atom.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the implications for the carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography can suppress fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our results have implications for climate policy and for the management of fire in terrestrial ecosystems.

The symbiosis between animals and microbes is one of the most widespread and important interactions in nature. The mutualism between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is a classic example of this relationship. In this study, we show that the squid provides a single glycan to its symbiont at a specific time each day. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbiont, and that it is catabolized by the symbiont to enhance the pH of the symbiont’s habitat, which in turn increases the level of oxygen available to the symbiont. This glycan is thus a critical regulator of the symbiosis.

Text data are ubiquitous and have been used to study a wide range of topics. However, the latent structure of text data is often unknown. We introduce a method to identify latent topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to study the US National Violent Death Reporting System, a database of violent death incidents. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that this method will be useful to many researchers.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The disease was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in Asia were favorable for the survival of the bacterium, and that the bacterium was reintroduced into Europe repeatedly, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the bacterium was not established in permanent reservoirs in Europe, but was introduced repeatedly via the trade routes. This highlights the importance of the trade routes for the spread of the disease, and the importance of the trade routes for the epidemiology of the plague.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important ecosystem engineers. They are also a valuable resource for the seafood industry. The sea-star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease affecting at least 20 species of asteroids. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of SSWD. We also show that the virus can be transmitted between asteroids and that the disease can be induced in healthy asteroids by virus-sized material. This study provides a strong basis for the development of control measures.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. The IL1RAP (IL1R3) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The admixture happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a step forward to understand the history of the Indian Ocean region. This article is protected by copyright. Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) that increases the activity of aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. We found that the protein interacts with the enzyme and that overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that the RNA base pairs with the 3′ untranslated region of two genes, cadA and galE, and that the base pairing interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA. The translation and base-pairing functions compete.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system, providing a wealth of information on crop status and condition. However, the information is not used to its full potential, and is often lost in the process of data aggregation. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be easily adapted to other countries and crops.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The dominant view is that information is maintained through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where information is maintained through adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to understand the response of soil respiration to climate change. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, totaling over 3,800 observations, to provide a more comprehensive understanding of the response of soil respiration to climate change. Our results provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Abridged)

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of the evolution of photosynthetic organisms. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is not known. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our results provide a molecular framework for the study of the evolution of plastid genomes in the context of the evolution of photosynthetic organisms. They also provide a model for the evolution of the molecular signature of the transition to a parasitic lifestyle.

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of occurrence of multiyear droughts in southwestern South Africa has been estimated through observations and climate models. However, model adequacy and insufficient horizontal resolution make it difficult to precisely quantify the changing likelihood of extreme droughts, given the small regional scale. Here, we use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear SSA rainfall deficits in past and future decades. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. The first example of a quasicrystal was discovered in the Khatyrka meteorite in 1969, and since then, many more have been found in meteorites and in experiments. The oldest known naturally occurring quasicrystal is the AlMnSiCuZr quasicrystal in the Murchison meteorite, which was found in 1990. Here, we report the discovery of a quasicrystal in the red trinitite, which was the first nuclear test explosion and was detonated on 16 July 1945.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the fifth isocyclic ring of (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key step in this process. The mechanism of this reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This paper describes the discovery of three classes of the enzyme that catalyzes this reaction, and their evolution is discussed.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroactive protein kinase ASK1 has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We found that ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes reduced disease severity, whereas ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. ASK1 signaling in microglia/macrophages played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a rationale for the use of a phase-specific manner in the future design of clinical trials. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occurred when conditions were warm were more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the probability of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral phenotypes of autism-risk genes and a potential target for the treatment of autism. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work offers the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a major store-operated Ca2+ (SOCE) channel that regulates a wide range of cellular functions. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that result in hematological abnormalities and muscle disease, respectively. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to study the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the study of spreading neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Read more)

The bat is the only mammal capable of flying, and bats are increasingly recognized as important reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are poorly understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent immunosuppressant that inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The results also highlight the importance of understanding the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats. (Read more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway supporting cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and used this inhibitor to identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells. We show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent SHMT inhibitor, and that this effect is not observed in normal cells. We also show that formate is a potent SHMT inhibitor in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. Thus, formate is a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and a targetable metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These findings have implications for the design of cancer therapies. (Less)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. The presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord suggests that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state may be a consequence of the ALS-linked proteins being part of a cellular biochemical pathway. Thus, the metastable state may be a consequence of the ALS-linked proteins being part of a cellular biochemical pathway.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to explore a wide range of fundamental physics phenomena and applications. The origin of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the study of the evolution of aquatic plants is a key to this problem. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, but the evolutionary history of many viruses is unknown because they have not been studied in the past. Here we present the first ancient viral genomes, which were recovered from human remains from the last ice age. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. The ancient viral sequences can be used to study the evolution of viruses in the past, and the study of ancient viral sequences can provide insights into the evolution of viruses in the present. The rate of sea level rise is one of the most visible and well-known effects of climate change. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is the longest time series available. We find that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that the acceleration is consistent with the climate change-induced rate of sea level rise. This finding is important because it provides a more accurate estimate of the rate of sea level rise, which is needed to assess the impacts of sea level rise and to plan for adaptation.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in America, but that this increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is seen across education levels, but is most pronounced among those with less education. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is reflected in the erosion of working-class pain.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, which is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This study demonstrates the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography for mechanistic enzymology and highlights the potential of this approach for the study of other enzyme active sites.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, has shown promising results in vitro and in vivo against SARS-CoV. Here, we show that remdesivir is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection, and that prophylactic treatment can prevent the development of clinical disease. These results support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS. The drug may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance, as the emergence of new coronaviruses is a major public health concern. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The study also shows that students’ suspensions can be reduced without increasing the number of suspensions. This is a major contribution to the literature on school suspensions, which has shown that suspensions are ineffective and costly. The study also has implications for the literature on the relationship between empathy and social outcomes. Finally, the study has implications for the literature on the relationship between teacher–student relationships and student outcomes.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage in living organisms. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct pol II stalling profiles. Intriguingly, pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This article is protected by copyright. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Virions must first be cleaved sequentially by cell-surface proteases, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. We found that precleaved MERS viruses used receptor-proximal, cell-surface proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry, whereas the more rigid uncleaved MERS viruses trafficked past these cell-surface proteases and into endosomes. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a large influence on these emissions, and it is therefore important to understand how to change these choices. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria by 50% led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% and a proportional decrease in meat meal sales of 14.5%. These results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. The results also suggest that it may be possible to achieve a more sustainable diet by increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria rather than by increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in the population as a whole. This approach could be used to achieve more sustainable diets in other settings.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the surfaceome of cancer cells is thought to be altered in a highly oncogene-specific manner. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a panel of breast epithelial cells stably expressing oncogenes, and find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We also find that oncogene-induced changes to the glycoproteome are extensive and differential, and that these changes are likely to be important for oncogene function. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Less)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout and vote share. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has a large number of mutations, and the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is rapidly evolving and has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides a molecular basis for the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Read more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can lead to cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this disease are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic induction of the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF)/CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) axis. We also show that CRFR1 triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε in cortical astrocytes, leading to up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) expression and edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema in hypobaric hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 antagonists may be useful in the treatment of cerebral edema. The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been “cherry picked”—searched for the strongest associations. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the formation of vascular networks. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor for the direct conversion of human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. The ETV2-induced ECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. These results indicate that ETV2 provides a useful tool for the generation of endothelial cells. Furthermore, the ETV2-induced ECs provide a promising therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders and the regeneration of organs. These findings will contribute to the development of vascular engineering for clinical applications. (Read more)

The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK are involved in a variety of human cancers. In this study, we show that zebrafish have three genes encoding ligands for ALK and LTK. We demonstrate that these ligands are essential for zebrafish pigmentation. We also show that the zebrafish augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, the light-reflecting cells of the eye and the zebrafish chromatophores, the light-reflecting cells of the skin. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and LTK and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate LTK in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the function of these RTKs in zebrafish and other organisms. (Read more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of immune response. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, using global and β-cell–specific knockout mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING−/− beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging of the genome. The selective packaging of the viral genome is a fundamental process for the production of infectious virions. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging. It also contributes to our understanding of the evolution of influenza A viruses. (Read more)

The atheroprone flow environment is a major risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis. The underlying mechanisms of the flow regulation of the vascular endothelium remain largely unknown. In this study, we identified the YAP/TAZ as a key mediator of the flow regulation of the vascular endothelium. We found that the activation of YAP/TAZ is a key event in the development of the atheroprone phenotypes and the atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the flow regulation of the vascular endothelium and a potential therapeutic target for the prevention of atherosclerosis.

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States. This has led to a substantial increase in the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. We show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that human-caused wildfires are disproportionately concentrated in areas with high population density and economic value. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire should focus on reducing the number of ignitions and the area burned by humans.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We then connect these changes to economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvement, (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances are more likely to experience improvement, and (iii) physically attractive neighborhoods are more likely to experience improvement. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic fortunes of neighborhoods.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel (sTRP1) that mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions to Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. We further demonstrated that Drosophila ortholog of sTRP1 (dTRPγ) is a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents, and dTRPγ is required for the avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and it should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Read more)

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne flavivirus that has recently emerged as a cause of severe disease in pregnant women, leading to birth defects. The pathogenesis of ZIKV is poorly understood, and there are no approved antiviral drugs. Here we use a mathematical model to study the dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We find that the virus grows rapidly within cells, and the time between infection of a cell and production of infectious virus is short. We also find that a drug that blocks viral replication can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load, but that the drug must be given early in the infection to be effective. Our results can inform the design of future clinical trials of antiviral drugs and drug combinations. (Less)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying processes are poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling and energy availability. We demonstrate that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbiont are a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. Our findings have implications for the management of coral reefs and the development of climate change adaptation strategies. (Less)

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients and immune responses. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors lead to the loss of the intestinal barrier, dysbiosis of the microbiome, and a regenerative response. We also show that the microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the interplay between intestinal tumors and the microbiome and suggests that targeting JNK signaling could be a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of intestinal tumors. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may lead to the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Finally, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is coincident with the eruption of Mount Takahe, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion. This unique volcanic event is the only known event in the last 700,000 y that led to both a poleward shift in the westerlies and ozone depletion. The coincidence of these events, and the plausibility of their link, suggest that the Mount Takahe eruptions may have triggered accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation. This is the first time that a volcanic eruption has been linked to deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poor. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to inform conservation and sustainable use of river ecosystems and to assess the impacts of climate change on fisheries. This study highlights the need to include inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable Mo-based oxide with a large capacity and low potential is realized, which is expected to be a promising candidate for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In mammals, this ability is lost during development, and the adult CNS is incapable of regenerating. In contrast, the Caenorhabditis elegans nervous system is capable of regenerating throughout adulthood, and the molecular mechanisms underlying this ability are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in C. elegans that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in other organisms. This discovery provides a unique platform for the discovery of novel genes involved in neuronal regeneration.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we use a population of wild monkeyflowers to map the distribution of recombination across the genome. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with hotspots of intense activity interspersed among cold regions. The distribution of hotspots is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the general pattern of recombination initiation and termination may have been conserved over evolution.

The resting brain is a dynamic and complex system, which is difficult to study. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks (RSNs) in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN was similar to the default mode network (DMN), whereas the subordinate RSNs were associated with Parkinson’s disease. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early Parkinson’s disease patients, whereas the subordinate RSNs were activated. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. The 5′ cap structure is also found on some small RNAs, such as tRNA and rRNA. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ NAD+ cap structure on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. This 5′ NAD+ cap structure is found on pre-mRNAs and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This 5′ NAD+ cap structure may have a role in modulating the stability and translation of these mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci in whole blood (WB) and monocytes (Monos) of people with diabetes are associated with metabolic memory. These epigenetic alterations are persistent for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. They also suggest that epigenetic alterations at specific loci may be used as a biomarker for the prediction of metabolic memory. This may help to identify people with diabetes who are at risk of developing complications and may benefit from intensive therapy. This may also help to identify people with diabetes who are at risk of developing complications and may benefit from intensive therapy.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that affects the brain and the gut. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the use of probiotics in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) is a key feature of fruit ripening. These VOCs are responsible for the characteristic aroma of ripening fruit and are important contributors to the flavor. The biosynthesis of these VOCs is not well understood, and the role of nitrogenous VOCs in fruit aroma is still controversial. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous VOCs in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous VOCs. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of VOCs in fruit and will be of interest to the broader scientific community.

Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, and the need to consider the thermal tolerance of species when assessing the impacts of climate change on the functioning of ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains two subfields, the superficial layer MEC (sMEC) and the deep layer MEC (dMEC), which are anatomically and functionally distinct. The sMEC contains grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for the formation of a map of the local environment. The dMEC is thought to be involved in the formation of a map of the global environment. Here, we show that grid cells are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells in the superficial layer of MEC. This suggests that grid cells might form a network that is largely segregated from those of other cell types. This finding is important for understanding the functional organization of the MEC. (Read more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the FT gene in the rootless parasite Cuscuta australis does not function in flowering induction of its host plants. Instead, we found that the FT protein is able to move from the host to the parasite, where it physically interacts with a dodder FD transcription factor to activate dodder flowering. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that dopamine-containing neurons in the substantivity contain tightly intertwined striosomal fibers and dopamine-containing dendrites, which form unique arborizations termed “striosome–dendron bouquets.” These bouquets likely represent specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We all have a sense of when two people are “clicking” or “not clicking.” But how do we know when two people are “clicking” with each other? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is a specialized cardiac pacemaker located in the right atrium. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for the generation of the heart rate, which is a critical determinant of cardiac output and blood pressure. The SAN is a highly specialized cell type that is responsible for the generation of the heart rate, and its function is tightly regulated by a number of mechanisms. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the function of SANCs, and that STIM1 is expressed in SANCs and is required for the maintenance of the normal function of the SAN. These studies reveal a previously unrecognized role for STIM1 in the regulation of Ca2+ signaling in SANCs. Our findings have important implications for our understanding of the mechanisms that regulate the function of the SAN. (Read more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant physiology has been debated for decades. Although Si has been shown to confer resistance to insect herbivores, the underlying mechanisms are still unclear. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, and that this effect is mediated by priming of the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact with each other in the priming of defense responses against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activation of macrophages and that modulation of the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase has a profound impact on the lipidome of macrophages.

Language processing is a complex cognitive task that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The dominant view is that information is maintained through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by intrinsic plasticity that downregulates neuronal firing rates. We show that this adaptive change in excitability can be used to write information into coupled dynamic variables that control the membrane potential. From these variables, information is continuously read back into the active membrane state for processing. This neuronal memory mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. We believe that this work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the siRNA-carrying DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

The impacts of nutrient loading on aquatic ecosystems are well documented, but the relative importance of point and nonpoint sources is poorly understood. We show that the majority of nutrient loading to a large lake is delivered by a small fraction of its tributaries. These findings have implications for the management of coastal ecosystems, as they suggest that small watersheds may be a significant source of nutrients to nearshore areas. Our results also highlight the importance of small watersheds in the context of climate change, as they are likely to be the first to be affected by increased precipitation intensity and frequency. Our findings suggest that the management of small watersheds may be a cost-effective way to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a system of interacting particles in a random potential, which is known to exhibit a strong tendency to concentrate in a few regions of the phase space. We show that the same phenomenon is at play in our system, and we provide a theoretical framework to understand the origin of this behavior.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We use a combination of in silico and in vivo experiments to show that NMDAR-Abs can change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and render cortical microcircuitry susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also provide a framework for understanding the effects of other types of antibodies on the brain. This may be important for the development of new treatments for autoimmune encephalitis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid climate change, which is driven by anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases. However, the Earth system has also experienced abrupt climate changes in the past, which can provide insights into the future. Here, we present a study on a rapid climate change that occurred ∼304 Ma, which was superimposed on a longer-term greenhouse climate state. We show that this event can be linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon and to an increase in atmospheric CO2. Earth system modeling indicates that this event can be linked to enhanced thermocline stratification and increased nutrient fluxes during an icehouse climate. This study provides insights into the future of the Earth system.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a panacea for tropical deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of policies to reduce tropical deforestation. We recommend that certification be used in conjunction with other policies to achieve the greatest conservation and climate benefits.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis. It is essential to organisms across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Read more)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major focus of evolutionary biology. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In contrast, species with polygenic sex determination have multiple alleles segregating within a single species, allowing for more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two female- and male-determining alleles interact to produce siblings with four possible sex classes. We find that polygenic sex determination can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the acquisition of a new sex determiner can create additional axes of variation for varied traits. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations. (Less)

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoid lipofuscin and photogenerated reactive oxygen species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoid lipofuscin. We found that intracellular Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe-dependent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products was reduced in the presence of Fe chelator deferiprone. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as morphological and functional optimizations are expected to be required to capture different prey types. Here we show that this is not the case for siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. We show that siphonophores can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type can evolve into specialists on other prey types. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of hominin research. The study of the hominin hand is complicated by the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, ∼1.42 Mya in an East African hominin from Kaitio, West Turkana, Kenya. This fossil suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of the human hand.

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway supporting cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We show that this inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that the inhibitor is defective in one-carbon metabolism in a subset of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma cell lines, and that this deficiency is a targetable metabolic deficiency of this cancer. Thus, we have developed a metabolic inhibitor that is effective in vitro and in vivo, and that is particularly effective in B-cell lines. This inhibitor is a potential therapeutic for a wide range of cancers.

The role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase consumption of these foods and dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a causal modeling approach to understand the effects of environmental change on people’s diets. This approach can be used to understand the effects of other environmental changes on people’s diets in other settings.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased food production by 200% since 1960. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that this trend is a consequence of the increasing size of modern farm machinery, which is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods.
